title: Taric is a toxic champion and his rework is terrible
body:
Taric time and time again shows up at the forefront of every terrible support-oriented meta. Ardent, funnel, tank meta - you name it and he's right up at the top, every time, as one of the worst enablers of obnoxious hyper carries taking over the game way sooner than they're supposed.

Nothing about this character is thought out very well and the sheer gold value he brings through shields and heals combined with his frankly unfair ultimate makes it so that any meta he can be decent in is automatically a meta in which he's top tier in. 

I have played Taric off and on since well before the rework, back to my beginning in season 4. I maintain good winrates on him for every season I've played him in. I can tell you with certainty that this rework is less healthy than the original kit; an ultimate like Tarics is basically the reason that damage creep needed to happen; because you lose automatically if you can't obliterate Tarics MVP(s) before the invulnerability pops. Except he has a multitude of tools to make it very difficult to do that, two of which are targeted and one of which covers a massive AOE so as to be very difficult to dodge.

It's time to admit that Taric is a problem champion. He doesn't need to be reverted but his kit needs a massive power down.

Ok then, let's break this down, shall we?

Taric's heals cost a shitload of mana. More mana than he can sustain before building anything other than a Glacial Shroud. His heals are far, far, FAR from efficient, and are mainly there to allow him to spam his passive once he gets a healthy mana supply.

His shield is a shield based on the recipient's %Max HP. It starts at 8, and tops at 12. It's also one of his abilities that you max next to last. Therefore, squishy targets get smaller shields. It's not even remotely close to a Janna shield or Karma shield. It's more of an afterthought active for clutch saves and to designate a Bastion target.

His Dazzle is the meat of his kit, but relies heavily on your ally being exactly where you need them, and not fleeing so you can land your stuns to help them. If they're on top of you, not so much of an issue, but chances are people will want to kill your squishy friend first.

His R is telegraphed and delayed, and lasts a moderately short time. It is a game changer at times, but not without its shortcomings. It's entirely possible to kill Taric or his ally before the invulnerability even hits them. Considering the burst in the game, this isn't hard to do. If he does manage to land it, you have to simply back off until it wears off. Or you can CC people hit by it, since they're not immune to CC.

Taric's base HP is also fairly low for a tank, and he really needs a few items under his belt to really be durable. This can be his downfall early game, because he REALLY needs to be building mana too, not only for his mana guzzling Q, but also so he can effectively use his passive.
 His rework is probably one of the healthiest reworks Riot has ever done, because there were incredibly few things that had to be fixed post launch, and he's remained very stable since then. There are a lot of Achilles' heels built into his kit, and a lot of windows of opportunity where you can either drive him to blow his mana to save his allies, or bait out his ultimate. Your assessment that he's toxic and broken is not only absurd, it's indicative of someone who hasn't actually played Taric, because if you did, you'd be HIGHLY AWARE of his weaknesses and weak points.
Of course, his largest weakness is being CC'd from a range. This is INCREDIBLY easy to do in this current meta, where Morgana and Zyra are top performing supports who can easily tear him to pieces since he's not really going to be building MR. This meta isn't particularly favorable to Taric outside of highly organized teams that can coordinate things and fill in the gaps in his weak moments.

Taric is not a problem, and if you disagree, please by all means show your work. You've made some boldly absurd statements without anything to actually back them up.

Fighting to outlast Tarics mana bar is not a healthy representation of gameplay; Sona is a horrible design for the same reason. Neither is "burst them or lose," which, in every meta that he shows up in and becomes either the biggest issue or the second biggest issue behind Lulu or Tahm, makes him almost automatically win teamfight. Hoping the Taric player screws up is not sufficient counterplay; not every champion can freely disengage against multiple invulnerable enemies. JFL if you actually get baited and waste your ult. Tarics E and passive are the only reasonable parts of his kit, marred by the fact that he quickly turns into one of the biggest stat balls in the game when he can mindlessly shit out healing and shielding without having to worry about missing any of it. 

His only weakness is being out ranged; this is a weakness I'm acutely familiar with. It's hardly a sufficient weakness when your kit is this loaded and it's not a relevant weakness in any situation where Taric is broken. 

Taric not being in a favored meta in soloQ does not mean his design is good. All poorly designed champions have dry spells.
Thresh and Blitz abusing the hook hitbox since day 1 for entire seasons is fine but god forbids a Tank/Enchanter to be good at his job.

But I do love how it is always the support that gets blamed and nerfed because damage is to high.

The metas you mentioned all revolve around team play. Ardent meta means buffing the carry into a hypercarry. Funnel meta means protecting the carry so they scale into it faster. Tank meta isn't as cut-and-dry, but the general purpose of a tank is to protect your team from damage by absorbing it yourself, with the expectation that you won't deal much damage yourself and you're relying on your team to do this (which is why you helped them survive). Champions that excel in these roles - like Taric - are harder to point the finger at because they rely on someone else doing the flashy things. Do they make it easier for those allies to do those flashy things? Yes, sometimes even too much easier, and power is power whether it's a resetting dash or a shield on someone with a resetting dash.

If the champions Taric helps get nerfed, that is also a power-down for Taric, and vice versa. If the combination is too powerful, should he get nerfed, or should they? I don't know.

I loved playing old Taric. He could actually accomplish things himself if he got into melee range and had enough mana and CDR to power his combo. He was also not a meme of himself.
People whine about Taric because of funneling and Sona/Taric comp bot lane. His ultimate and how his E work make it possible in most of the case. He could get changed but honestly I don't know how.
